what: 1. Navigating the Codification of the Political Administrative Division of Colombia (DIVIPOLA)
title: epiCo - Demographic module
text: DIVIPOLA standardized nomenclature designed DANE identification territorial entities (departments, districts, municipalities), non-municipalized areas, populated centers assigning unique numerical code territorial units. Colombia : 32 Departments (Administrative Division Level 1) 1102 Municipalities (Administrative Division Level 2) 1 Island 18 Non-municipalized areas 6678 Populated centers Two digits used codification departments, five digits used codification municipalities (first two department located). epiCo provides complete list departments municipalities codes built-dataset.

title: epiCo - Demographic module
text: epiCo provides built-dataset population projections Colombia national, departmental, municipality levels (provided DANE). Users can perform queries data using population_pyramid function, providing DIVIPOLA code territory interest year consult. Definitions age ranges plotting also provided : total number individuals proportion individuals
code: ibague_code <- 73001 # DIVIPOLA code for the city of Ibagu<U+00E9> year <- 2016 # Year to consult ibague_pyramid_2016 <- population_pyramid(ibague_code, year) # Population # pyramid (dataframe) for the city of Ibagu<U+00E9> in the year 2019 # dissagregated by sex head(ibague_pyramid_2016) #>   age population gender #> 1   0       3355      F #> 2   5       3776      F #> 3  10       4492      F #> 4  15       4605      F #> 5  20       4341      F #> 6  25       3888      F ibague_code <- 73001 # DIVIPOLA code for the city of Ibagu<U+00E9> year <- 2019 # Year to consult age_range <- 5 # Age range or window ibague_pyramid_2019 <- population_pyramid(ibague_code, year,   range = age_range,   gender = TRUE, total = TRUE,   plot = TRUE )

title: epiCo - Demographic module
text: Events epidemiological relevance reported SIVIGILA using official notification form (see link). epiCo provides function consult dictionaries ethnicity categories, special population groups, occupation codifications used SIVIGILA.
code:
demog_data <- data.frame(   id = c(0001, 002, 003, 004, 005),   ethnicity_label = c(3, 4, 1, 2, 5),   occupation_label = c(6111, 3221, 5113, 5133, 6111) )  describe_ethnicity(demog_data$ethnicity_label) # Description of ethnicities #> [1] "Poblacion ubicada en el Archipielago de San Andres, Providencia
  y Santa Catalina, con raices culturales afroanglo-antillanas,
  cuyos integrantes tienen rasgos socioculturales y linguisticos
  claramente diferenciados del resto de la poblacion afrocolombiana" #> [2] "Poblacion ubicada en el municipio de San Basilio de
  Palenque, departamento de Bolivar, donde se habla el palenquero,
  lenguaje criollo"                                                                                                                             #> [3] "Persona de ascendencia amerindia que comparten sentimientos
  de identificacion con su pasado aborigen, manteniendo rasgos y valores
  propios de su cultura tradicional, asi como formas de organizacion
  y control social propios"                                 #> [4] "Son comunidades que tienen una identidad etnica y cultural propia;
  se caracterizan por una tradicion nomada, y tienen su propio idioma
  que es el romanes"                                                                                                          #> [5] "Persona de ascendencia afrocolombiana que poseen una cultura
  propia, y tienen sus propias tradiciones y costumbre dentro de la relacion
  campo-poblado" # reported in the consulted dataset describe_occupation(   isco_codes = demog_data$occupation_label,   output_level = "unit" ) # Description of the occupations #> [[1]] #> [1] 6111 #>  #> [[2]] #> [1] 3221 #>  #> [[3]] #> [1] 5113 #>  #> [[4]] #> [1] 5133 #>  #> [[5]] #> [1] 6111 # reported in the consulted dataset

title: epiCo - Demographic module
text: epiCo tool produces analyses based epidemiological data extracted SIVIGILA provided user. epi_data built-file, shows example structure used package, one reported SIVIGILA. file contains cases municipalities Tolima years 2015–2021. following analyses use dengue cases reported Tolima 2019.
code: data("epi_data") data_event <- epi_data  data_tolima <- data_event[lubridate::year(data_event$fec_not) == 2019, ] head(data_tolima) #> # A tibble: 6 × 15 #>   fec_not    cod_pais_o cod_dpto_o cod_mun_o cod_pais_r cod_dpto_r cod_mun_r #>   <chr>      <chr>      <chr>      <chr>     <chr>      <chr>      <chr>     #> 1 2019-01-02 170        73         73001     NA         73         73001     #> 2 2019-01-15 170        73         73268     NA         73         73268     #> 3 2019-01-01 170        73         73200     NA         73         73200     #> 4 2019-01-12 170        73         73671     NA         73         73671     #> 5 2019-01-05 170        73         73671     NA         73         73671     #> 6 2019-01-05 170        73         73671     NA         25         25754     #> # ℹ 8 more variables: cod_dpto_n <chr>, cod_mun_n <chr>, edad <dbl>, #> #   sexo <chr>, per_etn <chr>, uni_med <chr>, ocupacion <chr>, estrato <chr>

title: epiCo - Demographic module
text: incidence rate feature epiCo requires incidence package produce modified incidence object. Instead count vector (matrix), transforms object provide rate element accounting number cases time period divided total number inhabitants specific region year. epiCo uses DANE population projections denominators; therefore, necessary provide administration level incidences calculated. groups incidence object within DIVIPOLA coding municipalities (level 2) departments (level 1), national estimation intended (level 0), function able estimate incidence rate.

what: 6. Estimation of risk by age group
title: epiCo - Demographic module
text: Normalization data key aspect epidemiology. epiCo allows age distribution cases normalizes epidemiological data age structure population. normalization allows us estimate age risk disease according age structure general population municipality, department, country certain year.
code: data_ibague <- data_tolima[data_tolima$cod_mun_o == 73001, ]  age_risk_data <- age_risk(   age = data_ibague$edad,   population_pyramid = ibague_pyramid_2019,   gender = data_ibague$sexo, plot = TRUE )

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: Using endemic channel visual strategy represent historical behavior disease specific region epidemic curve defines central tendency cases year upper lower limits cases expected vary. plot provides four areas known “\(\color{green}{\text{Success}}\)”, “\(\color{Gold}{\text{Safety}}\)”, “\(\color{orange}{\text{Warning}}\)”, “\(\color{Red}{\text{Epidemic}}\)” bands (Figure 1), later used define epidemiological situation region based current (observed) cases. broader definition methodology endemic channel provided Bormant (1999).  data needed build endemic channel weekly monthly incidence disease previous years region interest. epiCo asks least one year data, endemic channels typically estimated 5 7 years information. natural presume years provide better estimations since statistical analyses robust, important contextual information ensure transmission, surveillance, demographic conditions (among factors) changed period time. Regarding frequency data, weekly incidence may provide useful information disease behavior moment epidemiological warning raised; however, experience users context whether resolution data can achieved. Another common decision building endemic channel ignore previous epidemic years avoid misrepresenting traditional transmission dynamics. epiCo suggest epidemic years automatically, endemic_channel function provide option annotate outlier years decide whether include, ignore, adjust . data-gathering tips sources provided later vignette.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: statistical summary disease behavior, endemic channel provides central tendency measure (CTM) describe typical value historical data. Since nature epidemiological data tends normal, typically used CTM endemic channels geometric mean. CTM known better represent expected value data set skewed distribution /susceptible outliers (previous outbreaks). endemic_channel function uses geometric mean default CTM, arithmetic mean median can chosen according user’s experience context. important note geometric mean performs multiplication data, zero cases reported moment time, estimation leads zero CTM. avoid , epiCo’s endemic_channel function performs shift data sum one case (default value) observations, subtracts shift final calculation. avoid random selection shift, users can ask endemic_channel function find optimal value based de la Cruz & Kreft (2019), can also ask use weighted method described Habib (2012). Finally, endemic_channel function can perform Poisson test (unusual behavior method) historical data requested user taking account pertinence test, since mostly used scenarios diseases low incidence records. method uses arithmetic mean CTM.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: upper lower limits endemic channel provide confidence interval used define epidemiological bands previously described. epiCo’s endemic_channel function following preset limits according selected CTM: Arithmetic geometric mean CTM: mean +/- t value 95% CI multiplied variance data number observations. Median CTM: quantiles 0.25 0.75 lower upper limits, respectively. Poisson test (unusual behavior method): limits provided two-sided Poisson test 0.95% CI

what: 2. Historical data needed to build an endemic channel
title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: section provides strategies obtain, handle, gather historical data needed build endemic channel. presumes user either line list incidence data disease interest need consult historical data Colombian National Surveillance System (SIVIGILA). Regardless user´s case, goal section create incidence object historical data disease. object must account incidence single region (groups allowed endemic_channel function), must weekly monthly interval (epiweeks also allowed), must represent least one year information. broader understanding incidence package, please refer vignettes.

previous_headings: 2. Historical data needed to build an endemic channel
what: Historic incidence from the line list or SIVIGILA data
title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: endemic channel useful data immediate previous year available; however, always possible users outside surveillance institutions. option, users can access SIVIGILA’s line list data typically published second semester year (.e., data 2022 published second semester 2023). example, data provided data folder package used. data present data dengue cases municipalities Tolima years 2015 2021. case, use cases municipality Ibagué calculate respective endemic channel. users line list data, goal : clean handle data build incidence object (named incidence_historic previous example). key message list dates account event interest needed later used incidence package.
code: library(epiCo) library(incidence)  data("epi_data") data_event <- epi_data  data_ibague <- data_event[data_event$cod_mun_o == 73001, ]  ## Building the historic incidence data  incidence_historic <- incidence(data_ibague$fec_not,   interval = "1 epiweek" )  print(incidence_historic)

previous_headings: 2. Historical data needed to build an endemic channel
what: Setting up the data from incidence information
title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: Future versions epiCo’s endemic_channel function allow users import table accounting periods time (weeks months) count cases, specific information dates case, endemic channel can still built.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: gathering incidence data, users ready ask epiCo build endemic channel. endemic_channel function following parameters: incidence_historic: incidence object case counts previous years observations: numeric vector current observations (default = NULL) method: string mean calculation method preference (“median”, “mean”, “geometric”) “unusual_behavior” method (Poisson Distribution Test) (default = “geometric”) geom_method: string selected method geometric mean calculation (see epiCo’s geom_mean function) (default = “shifted”). outlier_years: numeric vector outlier (epidemic) years (default = NULL). outliers_handling: string handling decision regarding outlier years: ignored = data outlier years taken account (default). included = data outlier years take account. replaced_by_median = data outlier years replaced median taken account. replaced_by_mean = data outlier years replaced mean taken account. replaced_by_geom_mean = data outlier years replaced geometric mean taken account. ci: numeric value specify confidence interval use geometric method (default = 0.95). plot: boolean displaying plot (default = FALSE). output epiCo’s endemic_channel function dataframe observation, historical mean, confidence intervals, plot displaying four epidemiological bands, current observations (provided), methods outliers handling set user.

title: Building an Endemic Channel with epiCo
text: following example uses previously historic incidence accessed SIVIGILA data source build 2021 endemic channel Ibagué City.
code: observations <- sample(15:100, 52, replace = FALSE)  outlier_years <- c(2016, 2019)  ibague_endemic_chanel <- endemic_channel(   incidence_historic = incidence_historic,   observations = observations,   outlier_years = outlier_years,   plot = FALSE )  ibague_endemic_chanel$endemic_channel_plot

what: 1. Real travel times among Colombian municipalities
title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: Several approaches estimating proximity neighborhood point (region) developed literature. rely euclidean distances among centroids areas, whereas others rely contiguity approaches boundaries. epiCo aims propose new approach neighborhood estimation defining proximities among municipalities based real available infrastructure territory. important countries like Colombia, topology shapes connectivity interaction municipalities Euclidean distances boundaries may lead overestimation nearness reality one three mountain ranges one several rivers country may lead large travel distances times. estimate real travel times among Colombian municipalities, travel times matrix calculated based Bravo-Vega C., Santos-Vega M., & Cordovez J.M. (2022) study. travel times account fastest path connect one municipality municipalities friction map provides different speeds according presence quality roads, fluvial transport, walking possibilities.

title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: Since epiCo stores travel times among municipalities Colombia, definition neighborhood based expertise knowledge user regarding maximum travel time municipality considered neighbor. neighborhoods function receives parameters vector DIVIPOLA codes accounting municipalities consider potential neighbors threshold accounts maximum travel time (hours) municipality can another.
code: library(epiCo) library(dplyr) #>  #> Attaching package: 'dplyr' #> The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': #>  #>     filter, lag #> The following objects are masked from 'package:base': #>  #>     intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(incidence) data(divipola_table) cundinamarca_data <- dplyr::filter(   divipola_table,   NOM_DPTO == "CUNDINAMARCA" ) %>%   select(COD_MPIO, LATITUD, LONGITUD)  cundinamarca_neighborhood <- neighborhoods(   query_vector = cundinamarca_data$COD_MPIO,   threshold = 0.5 ) #> Warning in spdep::mat2listw(adjacency_matrix): style is M (missing); style #> should be set to a valid value  plot(cundinamarca_neighborhood, cbind(   cundinamarca_data$LATITUD,   cundinamarca_data$LONGITUD ))

title: Spatiotemporal analyses with epiCo
text: epiCo provides function perform Local Moran’s index analysis incidence object unique observations set Colombian municipalities. Internally, function reads incidence object’s groups DIVIPOLA codes : Estimate incidence rates using epiCo’s incidence_rate function. Evaluate epiCo’s neighborhoods function. necessary user provide administrative level groups account (0: national level, 1: department level, 2: municipality level), scale incidence rates estimated (cases per number inhabitants), travel time threshold neighborhood definition. following example uses cases municipalities Tolima year 2019.
code: data("epi_data") data_event <- epi_data  data_tolima <- data_event[lubridate::year(data_event$fec_not) == 2019, ] incidence_object <- incidence(   dates = data_tolima$fec_not,   groups = data_tolima$cod_mun_o,   interval = "12 months" )  monrans_tolima <- morans_index(incidence_object = incidence_object, level = 2) #> Warning in spdep::mat2listw(adjacency_matrix): style is M (missing); style #> should be set to a valid value #> Influential municipalities are:  #> 73024 with low incidence and low spatial correlation  #> 73124 with low incidence and low spatial correlation  #> 73236 with low incidence and low spatial correlation  #> 73461 with low incidence and low spatial correlation  #> 73616 with high incidence and high spatial correlation  #> 73622 with low incidence and low spatial correlation  #> 73671 with high incidence and high spatial correlation  #> 73870 with low incidence and low spatial correlation monrans_tolima$leaflet_map

what: Provides statistical tools for the analysis of vector-borne diseases in Colombia
title: Provides statistical tools for the analysis of vector-borne diseases in Colombia
text: epiCo provides statistical tools analysis demographic trends, spatiotemporal behavior, outbreak characterization vector-borne diseases Colombia.

title: Provides statistical tools for the analysis of vector-borne diseases in Colombia
text: can install development version epiCo GitHub :

title: Provides statistical tools for the analysis of vector-borne diseases in Colombia
text: reviewing current epidemiological bulletins published local Secretariats Health Colombia, identified opportunity create tool : - Include spatial demographic risk assessments routine epidemiological reports better identify population groups potential interventions. - Facilitate understanding different epidemiological profiles within region Colombia regarding onset, duration, magnitude, frequency outbreaks. - Strengthen transparency methods used outbreak analysis. - Provide informative context performing correlation regression analysis local socioeconomic climate data. package allows interoperable analyses linelist data SIVIGILA (accessible using Epiverse-TRACE package sivirep) spatial, socioeconomic, climate data (accessible using Epiverse-TRACE package ColOpenData. epiCo can used perform following main tasks municipality, departmental, national level: identify demographic vulnerabilities linelist data socioeconomic census, including risk assessment based age, gender, occupation, ethnicity. assess hot-spot analyses (Local Moran’s index) based real travel distances Colombia estimated Bravo-Vega C., Santos-Vega M., & Cordovez J.M. (2022). generate automated outbreak characterization (onset, duration, magnitude, frequency) using traditional methods endemic channel poisson tests unusual behavior, statistical process control methods ARIMA Control Chart outlier detection. estimate probability effective reproductive number (Rt) higher one (.e., outbreak onset) based work Parag, K.V., & Donnelly, C.. (2022) & Codeço, C.T., Villela, D.., & Coelho, F.C. (2018). perform correlation analyses categorical socioeconomic data, climate time series epidemiological data generate report potential drivers trends VBDs outbreaks. Future features include nowcasting assessment, underreport estimation, short-term forecasting. functionalities performed automatically epidemiological, demographic, spatial, socioeconomic data published Colombian institutions, methods can also customized well input data, hypothetical information can tested within package.

text: x numeric vector real values method Description methods: positive = positive values within x used calculation. shifted = positive zero values within x used adding shift value calculation subtratcting final result. optimized = optimized shifted method. See: De La Cruz, R., & Kreft, J. U. (2018). Geometric mean extension data sets zeros. arXiv preprint arXiv:1806.06403. weighted = probability weighted calculation gm negative, positive, zero values. See: Habib, E. . (2012). Geometric mean negative zero values. International Journal Research Reviews Applied Sciences, 11(3), 419-432. shift = 1 (default) positive value use shifted method epsilon = 1e-5 (default) minimum positive value consider optimized method.
